column1: Lond Daer Enedh (also spelt Ened) was a great harbour in Eriador founded by the Númenóreans.

column4: was founded by Númenors crown prince Tar-Aldarion on the estuary of the river Gwathló between  and .
column6: Chronology It was the first permanent settlement of the Númenóreans in Middle-earth. From here Aldarions Guild of Venturers began harvesting the local timber for the ship-building industry of Númenor.

column2: the deforestation of the outlying regions Enedwaith and Minhiriath became cataclysmic
column3: angering the local native population (ancestors of the Dunlendings)
column4: and they began to fight back with increasing ferocity
column6: and frequently burning the great wood-stores in "hit-and-run" attacks.

column1: By the time of the War of the Elves and Sauron in the middle of the Second Age
column2: this New Haven had become very well established
column3: and its name had shifted over the intervening one thousand years to Lond Daer
column5: it was one of the two beachheads of the Númenórean forces in Eriador that were used to support the Elves around .

column1: Lond Daers shipyards were starved of timber following the war
column2: as the forces of Sauron had burnt almost all of what remained in Enedwaith and Minhiriath. Once its shipbuilding yards were no longer practicable
column4: and the Númenórean hunger for ever more wealth shifted focus to the establishment of newer havens to the south
column6: Lond Daer was once again renamed
column7: being now one of several major ports in Middle-earth
column8: and was known as Lond Daer Enedh
column10: Númenor still maintained traffic on the Gwathló as far as the city of Tharbad.

column2: Elendil founded the realm of Arnor in the lands north of Lond Daer
column3: but the haven was now redundant
column5: control over the region was maintained from Tharbad. The ancient ruins of Lond Daer were still visible as late as the end of the Third Age
